text:
Pakistan on Monday lifted a ban on video-sharing site YouTube after Google launched a country-specific version ensuring the filtering out of content deemed blasphemous.

The Supreme Court in 2012 had ordered a ban on the site after the Innocence of Muslims was uploaded.

The American-made film depicted the Prophet Mohammed as a thuggish deviant and triggered protests across the Muslim world — including in Pakistan, where more than 20 people died in demonstrations.

Blasphemy is a contentious issue in Pakistan and the country has seen violent riots sparked by content considered offensive to Islam.

Last week Google said it had launched a localised version of the site in Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka, meaning Pakistani authorities can now ask Google to remove content deemed objectionable.

On Monday, authorities said the ban had been lifted.

“Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) Monday directed the Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to unblock YouTube with immediate effect,” a government official said. Wahajus Siraj, chief executive officer of internet service provider Nayatel Private Limited, confirmed receiving the instruction. He added that he did not find blasphemous content on the website, saying that some videos came up with a notification that they had been blocked.

Google has said that it would review requests before taking videos down. — AFP

Authorities can now ask Google to remove content deemed objectionable or blasphemous
title: Pakistan lifts YouTube ban after local version launch
